title: What are the vertical rows on the periodic table called? - Quora

response.answer_text: The “vertical rows” (of the periodic table) are called “columns” — or “families”. Some of the “families” have names — like “alkali metals” and “alkaline earths” for the first and second columns — well except in the first column H is not counted as an alkali metal, because H is not metallic (under any near ordinary conditions). The last column is called the “halogens” and the next to last column the “chalcogens”. Some other columns are given names also, but in any event the columns are usually described by a number - though there are different conventions, and one entails an further identification or A or B (& rarely C). The elements in a column share some certain characteristics or properties.
Well, the periodic table of elements is compromised of seven horizontal rows of elements called periods. The vertical columns that you have mentioned in your question are called groups or families.
